Name: Babylonian Verse Account of Nabonidus
Short Description: A poetic and polemical text composed in Akkadian to condemn the last Neo-Babylonian king, Nabonidus. Written from a priestly perspective, the text accuses him of impiety, self-deification, and neglect of Marduk’s cult, portraying his rule as a disruption of cosmic and ritual order. It frames Nabonidus’s withdrawal from Babylon and his religious innovations as causes for divine abandonment, culminating in his political downfall. The text justifies the rise of Cyrus the Great as a divinely sanctioned correction.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Shadow, Persona, Hero, Terrible Father, Wise Old Man
Neumann Stages Tags: Battle with the Dragon, Divine Intervention, Death, Mythic Ordering of Reality, Return to the Community
Socio-political Tags: Priestly / Theocratic, Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Royal, Subversive / Revolutionary
Literary Forms Tags: Poetry, Narrative, Myth, Essay / Argument, Record / Chronicle
Literary Themes Tags: Ritual / Devotional, Historical Reflection, Political, Tragic / Lamentation, Didactic / Ethical, Prophetic / Revelation, Subversive

Name: Weidner Chronicle
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism (Single Principle), Subversion (Negation), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Short Description: A text that recounts a legendary list of past kings and their treatment of the Babylonian cult center of Esagil (temple of Marduk). It presents a moral-political theology: those kings who honored Marduk and Esagil prospered, while those who neglected or disrespected it met ruin. It retroactively constructs a theological justification for Babylon’s centrality and religious supremacy. The narrative functions as a mirror and warning to later rulers, urging them to uphold piety and ritual correctness as conditions for legitimate rule.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Shadow, Wise Old Man, Hero, Terrible Father, Initiator

Name: Commentary on Enūma Anu Enlil
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Logic / Formal Reasoning, Astronomy, Philosophy, History, Political Science / Law, Education
Short Description: A scholarly, explanatory companion to the foundational Mesopotamian omen series Enūma Anu Enlil, which contains celestial omens interpreted to forecast events affecting the king, the state, and the natural world. This commentary reflects a shift toward systematized intellectual engagement with traditional knowledge. It breaks down complex omen formulations, clarifies ambiguous terms, references older lexical lists, and sometimes offers variant readings or rationales for interpretive judgments.
Neumann Stages Tags: Mythic Ordering of Reality, Divine Intervention, Initiation
Category: Commentary on an Astrological Guide to Statecraft
Socio-political Tags: Priestly / Theocratic, Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Scholarly, Mystical / Initiatory
Literary Forms Tags: Commentary / Exegesis, Glossary / Taxonomy, Manual / Instruction, Analysis, Record / Chronicle, Fragment
Literary Themes Tags: Ritual / Devotional, Metaphysical, Epistemological / Hermeneutics, Political, Didactic / Ethical, Cosmological

Name: Achaemenid Administrative Texts from Babylon
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: A corpus of Akkadian cuneiform tablets that document economic, legal, and ritual transactions under Persian imperial rule. Produced by temple scribes and local officials, the texts include records of grain rations, land leases, tax payments, labor assignments, and temple provisions. Though bureaucratic in tone, they reveal the integration of Babylonian institutions into the Achaemenid imperial system.
Socio-political Tags: Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Priestly / Theocratic, Royal, Warrior / Imperial, Merchant / Cosmopolitan
Literary Forms Tags: Proclamation / Decree, Record / Chronicle, Rulebook / Code, Fragment

Name: Murašû Archive
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: A collection of over 800 clay tablets is an archive, which records the activities of the Murašû family firm, a powerful private enterprise involved in managing agricultural land, renting equipment, lending capital, and collecting taxes on behalf of the Persian administration. These documents include contracts, leases, promissory notes, and receipts, showcasing how the family intermediated between imperial authorities and local tenants. The archive reveals a sophisticated legal and economic system where land, labor, and water rights were carefully negotiated and enforced. It also provides evidence of the integration of imperial bureaucracy with local Babylonian scribal traditions.
Socio-political Tags: Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Merchant / Cosmopolitan, Warrior / Imperial
Literary Forms Tags: Record / Chronicle, Personal Writings, Proclamation / Decree, Rulebook / Code, Manual / Instruction

Name: Astronomical Diaries
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: The Astronomical Diaries are a long-running Babylonian record of celestial phenomena, market prices, political events, and environmental conditions. Compiled by temple scribes, the diaries served as both an empirical archive and a predictive corpus—systematically tracking patterns in order to correlate movements in the heavens with events on earth.
Neumann Stages Tags: Divine Intervention, Mythic Ordering of Reality
Socio-political Tags: Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Scholarly, Warrior / Imperial
Literary Themes Tags: Historical Reflection, Political, Cosmological, Didactic / Ethical

Name: Lunar Ephemerides
Metaphysical Tags: Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Mathematics, Logic / Formal Reasoning, Astronomy, Education
Short Description: Predictive tables that calculate the positions and phases of the moon using mathematical rules. Though empirical in method, they served religious and political functions—timing rituals, legitimizing rulers, and aligning society with cosmic order.
Socio-political Tags: Priestly / Theocratic, Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Scholarly, Royal, Warrior / Imperial

Name: Almanacs
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism (Single Principle)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Mathematics, Logic / Formal Reasoning, Astronomy, Education, Agriculture
Short Description: Month-by-month predictive texts compiled by temple scholars. They combine astronomical forecasts, ritual instructions, omen logic, and agricultural guidance. Used to align human activity with celestial rhythms, these texts reflect a deeply embedded cosmological worldview.
